text: Fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence Solving Problems by Searching Problem-Solving Agent ‚Ä¢ A problem-solving agent is a goal-based agent and use atomic representations. ‚Ä¢ In atomic representations, states of the world are considered as wholes, with no internal structure visible to the problem solving algorithms. ‚Ä¢ Intelligent agents are supposed to maximize their performance measure. Achieving this is sometimes simplified if the agent can adopt a goal and aim at satisfying it. ‚Ä¢ Problem formulation is the process of deciding what actions and states to consider, given a goal. ‚Ä¢ The process of looking for a sequence of actions that reaches the goal is called search. ‚Ä¢ A search algorithm takes a problem as input and returns a solution in the form of an action sequence. ‚Ä¢ Once a solution is found, the carrying actions it recommends is called the execution phase. ‚Ä¢ A problem-solving agent has three phases: ‚Ä¢ problem formulation, searching solution and executing actions in the solution. Problem-Solving Agent Well-defined problems A problem can be defined by five components: ‚Ä¢ initial state, actions, transition model, goal test, path cost. INITIAL STATE: The initial state that the agent starts in. ACTIONS: A description of the possible actions available to the agent. ‚Ä¢ Given a particular state s, ACTIONS(s) returns the set of actions that can be executed in s. ‚Ä¢ Each of these actions is applicable in s. TRANSITION MODEL: A description of what each action does is known as the transition model ‚Ä¢ A function RESULT(s,a) that returns the state that results from doing action a in state s. ‚Ä¢ The term successor to refer to any state reachable from a given state by a single ‚Ä¢ The state space of the problem is the set of all states reachable from the initial state by any sequence of actions. ‚Ä¢ The state space forms a graph in which the nodes are states and the links between nodes are actions. ‚Ä¢ A path in the state space is a sequence of states connected by a sequence of actions. Problem-Solving Agent Well-defined problems GOAL TEST: The goal test determines whether a given state is a goal state. PATH COST: A path cost function that assigns a numeric cost to each path. ‚Ä¢ The problem-solving agent chooses a cost function that reflects its own performance measure. ‚Ä¢ The cost of a path can be described as the sum of the costs of the individual actions along the path. ‚Ä¢ The step cost of taking action a in state s to reach state s‚Ä≤ is denoted by c(s, a, s‚Ä≤). ‚Ä¢ A SOLUTION to a problem is an action sequence that leads from the initial state to a goal state. ‚Ä¢ Solution quality is measured by the path cost function, and an OPTIMAL SOLUTION has the lowest path cost among all solutions. Problem Example Travelling in Romania ‚Ä¢ On holiday in Romania; currently in Arad. ‚Ä¢ Flight leaves tomorrow from Bucharest Formulate goal: ‚Ä¢ be in Bucharest Formulate problem: ‚Ä¢ states: various cities ‚Ä¢ actions: drive between cities Find solution: ‚Ä¢ sequence of cities, e.g., Arad, Sibiu, Fagaras, Bucharest Problem Example Travelling in Romania: A simplified road map Problem Example Travelling in Romania ‚Ä¢ Travelling in Romania problem can be defƒ±ned by: initial state: in Arad actions: transition model: is the graph successor function S(x) = set of action{state pairs e.g., S(Arad) = { <Arad ‚Üí Zerind,Zerind>, <Arad ‚Üí Sibiu,Sibiu>, < Arad ‚Üí Timisoara,Timisoara> } goal test: in Bucharest path cost: sum of distances, number of actions executed, etc. c(x; a; y) is the step cost, assumed to be ‚â• 0 ‚Ä¢ A solution is a sequence of actions leading from the initial state to a goal state Problem Example vacuum world States: ‚Ä¢ The state is determined by both the agent location and the dirt locations. ‚Ä¢ The agent is in one of two locations, each of which might or might not contain dirt. ‚Ä¢ Thus, there are 2 √ó 22 = 8 possible world states. Initial state: Any state can be designated as the initial state. Actions: Each state has just three actions: Left, Right, and Suck. Transition model: ‚Ä¢ The actions have their expected effects, except that moving Left in the leftmost square, moving Right in the rightmost square, and Sucking in a clean square have no effect. ‚Ä¢ The transition model defines a state space. Goal test: This checks whether all the squares are clean. Path cost: Each step costs 1, so the path cost is the number of steps in the path. Problem Example vacuum world: state space for the vacuum world ‚Ä¢ Links denote actions: L = Left, R =Right, S = Suck. Problem Example 8-puzzle ‚Ä¢ The 8-puzzle consists of a 3√ó3 board with eight numbered tiles and a blank space. ‚Ä¢ A tile adjacent to the blank space can slide into the space. ‚Ä¢ The object is to reach a specified goal state. Problem Example 8-puzzle States: A state specifies the location of each of the eight tiles and the blank in one of the nine squares. Initial state: Any state can be designated as the initial state. ‚Ä¢ Note that goal can be reached from exactly half of the possible initial states. Actions: Movements of the blank space Left, Right, Up, or Down. ‚Ä¢ Different subsets of these are possible depending on where the blank is. Transition model: Given a state and action, this returns the resulting state; Goal test: This checks whether the state matches the goal configuration Path Cost: Each step costs 1, so the path cost is the number of steps in the path. Problem Example 8-puzzle ‚Ä¢ The 8-puzzle belongs to the family of sliding-block puzzles, ‚Ä¢ This family is known to be NP-complete. ‚Ä¢ Optimal solution of n-Puzzle family is NP-hard. ie NO polynomial solution for the problem. ‚Ä¢ The 8-puzzle has 9!/2=181, 440 reachable states. ‚Ä¢ The 15-puzzle (on a 4√ó4 board) has around 1.3 trillion states, ‚Ä¢ The 24-puzzle (on a 5 √ó 5 board) has around 1025 states Real-World Problems ‚Ä¢ Route-finding problem is defined in terms of specified locations and transitions along links between them. ‚Ä¢ Route-finding algorithms are used in a variety of applications such as Web sites and in-car systems that provide driving directions. ‚Ä¢ VLSI layout problem requires positioning millions of components and connections on a chip to minimize area, minimize circuit delays, minimize stray capacitances, and maximize manufacturing yield. Searching for Solutions ‚Ä¢ A solution is an action sequence and search algorithms considers various possible action sequences. ‚Ä¢ The possible action sequences starting at the initial state form a search tree with the initial state at the root; ‚Ä¢ The branches are actions and the nodes correspond to states in the state space of the problem. ‚Ä¢ Expanding the current state is application of each legal action to the current state and generation of a new set of states. ‚Ä¢ The current state is the parent node, newly generated states are child nodes ‚Ä¢ Leaf node is a node with no children in the tree. ‚Ä¢ The set of all leaf nodes available for expansion at any given point is called the frontier. ‚Ä¢ Search algorithms all share this basic structure; they vary primarily according to how they choose which state to expand next: search strategy. Partial Search Trees for Travelling in Romania initial state Partial Search Trees for Travelling in Romania After expanding Arad Partial Search Trees for Travelling in Romania After expanding SibiuInfrastructure for Search Algorithms ‚Ä¢ Search algorithms require a data structure to keep track of the search tree that is being constructed. ‚Ä¢ Each node n of the tree contains four components: n.STATE: the state in the state space to which the node corresponds; n.PARENT: the node in the search tree that generated this node; n.ACTION: the action that was applied to the parent to generate the node; n.PATH-COST: the cost of the path from the initial state to the node, Informal Description of Graph Search Algorithms function GRAPH-SEARCH(problem) returns a solution, or failure ‚Ä¢ initialize frontier using initial state of problem ‚Ä¢ initialize explored set to be empty ‚Ä¢ loop do ‚Ä¢ if frontier is empty then return failure ‚Ä¢ choose a leaf node from frontier and remove it from there ‚Ä¢ if node contains a goal state then return corresponding solution ‚Ä¢ add node to explored set ‚Ä¢ expand node, adding resulting nodes to frontier only if not in frontier or explored set Informal Description of Graph Search Algorithms ‚Ä¢ To avoid exploring redundant paths is to remember them. ‚Ä¢ Explored set (also known as closed list) remembers every expanded node. ‚Ä¢ The frontier needs to be stored in such a way that search algorithm can easily choose next node to expand according to its preferred strategy. ‚Ä¢ The appropriate data structure for this is a queue. ‚Ä¢ Queues are characterized by the order in which they store the inserted nodes. ‚Ä¢ First-in, first-out or FIFO queue, which pops the oldest element of the queue; (QUEUE) ‚Ä¢ Last-in, first-out or LIFO queue (also known as STACK), which pops the newest element ‚Ä¢ PRIORITY QUEUE, which pops the element of the queue with the highest priority according to some ordering function. ‚Ä¢ The explored set can be implemented with a hash table to allow efficient checking for repeated states. Measuring Problem-Solving Performance ‚Ä¢ We can evaluate a search algorithm‚Äôs performance in four ways: Completeness: Is the algorithm guaranteed to find a solution when there is one? Optimality: Does the strategy find the optimal solution? Time complexity: How long does it take to find a solution? Space complexity: How much memory is needed to perform the search? Measuring Problem-Solving Performance ‚Ä¢ The typical measure for time and space complexity is the size of the state space graph, |V | + |E|, where V is the set of vertices (nodes) of the graph and E is the set of edges (links). ‚Ä¢ This is appropriate when the graph is an explicit data structure. ‚Ä¢ In AI, graph is often represented implicitly by the initial state, actions, and transition model and is frequently infinite. For these reasons, complexity is expressed in terms of three quantities: ‚Ä¢ b - maximum branching factor of the search tree ‚Ä¢ d - depth of the least-cost solution ‚Ä¢ m - maximum depth of the state space (may be ‚àû) ‚Ä¢ Time is often measured in terms of the number of nodes generated during the search, and space in terms of the maximum number of nodes stored in memory. Uninformed Search Strategies ‚Ä¢ Uninformed strategies use only the information available in the problem definition. ‚Ä¢ All they can do is generate successors and distinguish a goal state from a non-goal state. ‚Ä¢ All search strategies are distinguished by the order in which nodes are expanded. ‚Ä¢ Uninformed (blind) Search Strategies are: ‚Ä¢ Breadth-first Search ‚Ä¢ Uniform-cost Search ‚Ä¢ Depth-first Search ‚Ä¢ Depth-limited Search ‚Ä¢ Iterative Deepening Search Breadth-First Search ‚Ä¢ Breadth-first search is a simple strategy in which the root node is expanded first, then all the successors of the root node are expanded next, then their successors, and so on. ‚Ä¢ All nodes are expanded at a given depth in search tree before any nodes at next level are expanded. ‚Ä¢ Breadth-first search uses a FIFO queue for the frontier Breadth-First SearchBreadth-First Search: Example Frontier Explored A empty Breadth-First Search: Example Frontier Explored B A C Breadth-First Search: Example Frontier Explored C A, B D E Breadth-First Search: Example Frontier Explored D A, B, C E F G Properties of Breadth-First Search Complete? Yes if branching factor b is finite Time? 1 + b + b2 + b3 + : : : + bd = O(bd+1), i.e., exponential in depth d Space? O(bd+1) (keeps every node in memory) Optimal? Yes (if cost = 1 per step); not optimal in general Breadth-First Search ‚Ä¢ Time and memory requirements for breadth-first search assuming branching factor b = 10; 1 million nodes/second; 1000 bytes/node. ‚Ä¢ The memory requirements are a bigger problem for breadth-first search than is the execution time. Uniform-Cost Search ‚Ä¢ When all step costs are equal, breadth-first search is optimal because it always expands the shallowest unexpanded node. ‚Ä¢ In general, it is not optimal when step costs are different. ‚Ä¢ By a simple extension, we can find an algorithm that is optimal with any step-cost function. ‚Ä¢ Uniform-cost search expands node n with the lowest path cost g(n). ‚Ä¢ This is done by storing the frontier as a priority queue ordered by g. ‚Ä¢ Uniform-cost search is equivalent to breadth-first if step costs are all equal Uniform-Cost SearchProperties of Uniform-Cost Search Complete? Yes nodes expanded in increasing order of path cost Depth-First Search ‚Ä¢ Depth-first search always expands deepest unexpanded node in frontier of search tree. ‚Ä¢ As nodes are expanded, they are dropped from frontier, so then search ‚Äúbacks up‚Äù to next deepest node that still has unexplored successors. ‚Ä¢ Depth-first search uses a LIFO queue (STACK). ‚Ä¢ A LIFO queue means that the most recently generated node is chosen for expansion. ‚Ä¢ This must be the deepest unexpanded node because it is one deeper than its parent. Depth-First Search ‚Ä¢ Depth-first search on a binary tree. ‚Ä¢ Explored nodes with no descendants in the frontier are removed from memory. ‚Ä¢ Nodes at depth 3 have no successors and M is the only goal node. No Depth-Limited Search ‚Ä¢ The failure of depth-first search in infinite state spaces can be alleviated by supplying depth-first search with a predetermined depth limit ‚Ñì. ‚Ä¢ Nodes at depth ‚Ñì are treated as if they have no successors. ‚Ä¢ This approach is called depth-limited search. ‚Ä¢ The depth limit solves the infinite-path problem. ‚Ä¢ Unfortunately, it also introduces an additional source of incompleteness if we choose ‚Ñì < d, that is, the shallowest goal is beyond the depth limit. ‚Ä¢ Depth-limited search will also be non-optimal if we choose ‚Ñì > d. ‚Ä¢ Its time complexity is O(b‚Ñì) and its space complexity is O(b‚Ñì). ‚Ä¢ Depth-first search can be viewed as a special case of depth-limited search with ‚Ñì=‚àû.
